Hi Colin-

> Possibly but I think Ken makes a good point about the activation fn
> selection re-using the regularities inherent in the connection weight
> generating CPPN. If we don't need to re-use those regularities then
> the CPPN can evolve connections to the activation fn output(s) that
> are completely isolated from the connection weight (sub)network.

Yes. Reading Ken's email and thinking about it more convinced me that you
and Ken are right. I do think there is something to be said that we are
asking the CPPN to serve many different masters simultaneously, which may
prevent it from being good at all of them, but I think the benefits of
keeping it baked into the CPPN here outweigh this (potential) cost. Plus,
evolution tends to deal well with high levels of entanglement (pleiotropy
and epistasis). 

> 
> 
>>  Do you have any test problems in mind? Problems that require the use of many
>>  different types of activation functions?
> 
> 
> This goes back to a discussion ages ago about using neurons with
> different activation functions or neurons with multiple input
> connection points (collectors?) with each collector totalling its
> input and feeding a parameter into diffeerent activation functions.
> E.g. you might have a neuron with two collectors and the activation
> function might be to multiply the inputs from the two collectors.
> 
> Such a model would perhaps be a good generalisation of both
> traditional artificial neural nets and Genetic Programming. At some
> point I did have a think about where CPPNs fit in with that idea and I
> think using extra outputs from a CPPN to specify activation functions
> per node is part of the answer. Thinking about it some more now I can
> also see that in addition to an x,y target coordinate being output
> from a CPPN we could also have a collector index output as well. So
> x,y --> x,y,c
> 
> Really you need a flexible codebase to play about with all of these
> possibilities and the various combinations of systems, hence the
> earlier discussion about future SharpNEAT development.

Cool. I look forward to seeing what comes of it.
> 
> Colin.
